statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Wyoming 71, Montana State 70
article.story: BILLINGS, Mont. (AP) -- Thanks to senior center Alex Dunn, Wyoming was able to collect its first road victory of the season. Dunn's 15-foot jumper off an inbound pass at the buzzer lifted Wyoming over a scrappy Montana State 71-70 Saturday night. Dunn's high-arcing game winner came from the left side of the basket along the base line after catching a pass from reserve guard James Ebert. The clutch shot aborted a huge comeback by the Bobcats in the final 10 minutes of play. "We had it drawn up to get a back screen and come around the backside," Dunn, who finished with 13 points, said. "Fortunately I was able to pop out and get an open shot. I just read it because they had so many guys in there, I had to pop out." The Cowboys appeared to be well on the way to their 11th straight win over Montana State at the midway point of the second half, holding a seemingly comfortable 55-39 lead. But the smaller Bobcats, who more often than not have been forced to live and die from the 3-point arc, hit eight long-range bombs down the stretch to quickly cut into the Cowboys big lead. The key figure in the late barrage was junior guard JaRon Jefferson, who had four of the eight 3-pointers, including the one with :17 seconds remaining, that gave Montana State its first lead, 70-69, since early in the game. After surrendering the lead, the Cowboys got the ball inside to Dunn, but it was knocked away from him and out of bounds as he was working his way down the lane for a shot with :01.1 seconds left. Following a Wyoming timeout, Ebert initially had problems getting the ball back into play before getting it to Dunn, who just had time to catch and shoot it. "Alex caught it and knocked it down like you hoped he would," Wyoming coach Steve McClain said. "It was great for him, and we hope that will give him some confidence." The Cowboys still appeared to be in good shape with 5½ minutes remaining when senior guard Jay Straight hit a short jumper to give the Pokes a 62-54 lead. As it turned out, though, that was Wyoming's last field goal until Dunn's game winner. While the Cowboys were going without a field goal, Montana State was lighting it up from the arc. Jefferson and Branden Miller each hit a pair of treys, while the other came from reserve guard Casey Durham. Montana State tied school records for both 3-point attempts (35) and makes (14). "It was getting kind of crazy out there because they had five guards in the game some times and our guys didn't know who to defend," McClain said. "It's not easy to win up here because this is a big game for Montana State. Two years ago, we came in here with a team that we took to the NCAA Tournament and needed to run a ball screen at the end to win it." Straight finished with a game-high 24 points and pulled down seven rebounds before fouling out in the final minute. The Cowboys were forced to play without their top 3-point shooter for the season in sophomore guard Steve Leven. Leven, the Mountain West Conferences leading scorer, was not with the Cowboys Saturday after suffering a partially torn MCL in a knee during a practice session Thursday. Early reports indicate that he will be lost to the Cowboys from two to four weeks.
